content: Thunderbird is just the messenger; the implication is that your email host is rejecting the password. This sometimes happens when the email host updates security settings. Possibly, if you share the email domain (e.g., gmail, spectrum, etc) and your server settings for incoming and outgoing, some suggestions may surface. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: I do not understand your problem. Your post indicates that you are using the beta version successfully.
creator: davidsk

content:
If they are both windows, it will work (It may also work with Linux and mac, but I don't know those). - first, install Thunderbird on the second pc and exit. Do NOT restart until final step below. - on original PC, exit thunderbird - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to a USB stick from original pc - copy the Thunderbird folder from USB stick to 

   c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming   on the second pc (this will prompt for overwrite. Allow that.)

- start thunderbird on second pc and it should be identical
creator: davidsk

content: There is no blackandwhite with the junk filter; it requires ongoing training and periodic identifying of what is and isn't junk. Something in that email triggered the junk setting. There is no 'white list' feature. Here is more info: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages
creator: davidsk

content: I am unsure of your predicament. There is no need to uninstall if you forgot an account's password. However, if using Windows, just type 'uninstall' in the search box on task bar and the add/remove app module should appear. Follow the prompts.
creator: davidsk
